bibl.title: [Claim] 1841 Feb. 9, State of Arkansas, County of Washington / Susan Mosley
bibl.note: This document, dated February 9, 1841 is an inventory of property, belonging to Sarah Mosley of the Cherokee Nation East of the Mississippi, that was taken from her between 1829 and 1832 by European settlers.

div.p:
An Inventory of property Taken away from Susan Mosley a native of the cherokee nation East of the
Mississippi __ by the whites uss nine head of horses one negro woman fifty five head of cattle one yoke of oxens one wagon one hundrd hundred and twenty five head of hogs nine head of goats two rifle guns one mans saddle and twenty five acres of corn Standing in the field In all amounting to two thousand three hundred and forty two dollars and fifty cents

The above property priced as follows
One negro woman at __ $300"00
fifty five head of cattle at __ 275"00
nine head of horses at __ 395"00
one yoke of oxen and wagon at __ 175"00
125 head of hogs at __ 125"00
nine head of goats at __ 18"00
two rifle guns at __ 35"00
one mans sadle saddle at __ 18"00
Seventy five acres of corn in the field at 1000"00
The above property was taken in July 1829
$2341"00

State of Arkansas
County of Washington
This day personally appeared befor before me the under signed an acting justice of the peace in and for said County Susan Mosley and John Pinder and made oath in due form of law that the above
facts set fourth in the foregoing Inventory and account are just and true agreeable to the selling prices of Such property in the Cherokee Nation East of the Mississipee and that said property were actially actually and forceably taken from her the said Susan Mosly in July in the year one thousand Eight hundred and twenty nine Sworn to and Subscribed before me this 9th day of February 1841
div.closer:
Susan her mark Mosly
John his mark Pender Jon Newman
State of Arkansas County of Washington
This day personally appeared before me the undersigned acting Justice of the peace in and for said county George W Freeman and after being duly sworn deposith and saith that he lived in the Cherokee nation East of the Mississipee Mississippi in July 1829 about fourteen miles from Susan Mosley and that he frequently heard of the whites being at her house and of them taking her property off and that they finely strip her of all her property__ that she was a woman in good circumstances previous to that time and further this defenanent was not Sworn to and described before me the 9th of February 1841 G.W. Freeman Jon Newman
State of Arkansas County of Washington
These are to certify that Jonathan Newman , whose name is subscribed to the answered and foregoing instruments of writing is an acting Justice of the Peace within and for said County of Washington duly commissioned and sworn, that her signature is genuine, and that to all acts gone by him in that capacity, full faith and credit are due and ought to be given, as well in counts of Justice as thereout.
In testimony whereof I have here unto set my hand as clerk of the circuit court within and for said County and affixed the seal of said Count at my office in Fayettville this fifteenth day of February AD 1841 B.H. Purson Clerk
Claim No. 205
Susan Mosely for Spoilations from 1829
to 1832
